With no prior knowledge of the series, I only picked this anime up because I was seeing fairly glowing reviews and an impressively high score on this site. Unfortunately, I'm in the undesirable position of being one of the bearers of bad news: This show is dreadful.
Classroom of the elite starts off fairly weak, presenting some vapid quotes like, "Are humans really equal?" and an opening sequence that displays a general lack of care. It only took me a few minutes to realize what I was watching was yet another light novel adaptation (if you're not familiar with light novels, the fact that this showis an adaptation of one is not a good thing). The premise is almost entirely unoriginal, but I've always thought that it's not so much about originality of concept, but rather how one uses the ideas and inspiration they take from other stories to craft something unique or memorable of their own. 


The problem, though, is that there is nothing of quality to speak of in this show. Not even remotely. The story is derived from countless battle school anime where kids in a given school fight for ranking and prestige. In this case, they prove their worth through academic standings. To "spice things up" the kids have to live on campus and receive an allotted amount of funds each month that fluctuates depending on their performance. The class we follow starts out at the bottom rung of the hierarchy, class D, and we are to see their journey to class A. The execution of this concept is poorly handled, though, in part due to a simple lack of imagination and a pacing structure that would give Charlotte a run for its money. At this rate, I have my doubts the kids'll make it to C, as the show has quickly devolved into a sort of "adventures with Ayanokouji-kun and friends..." 


Yes, everything about this is hacky, even down to the details of the kids having to live on campus, but again this wasn't even the upsetting part. The unfortunate truth is anyone looking for any sort of unique or inspired take on the already super saturated "highschool battle school" subgenre is going to be severely let down here.


All that's left worth talking about is our characters... I was hoping they could save this sinking ship but I'll just come out and say it: They are all walking tropes. No attention to detail or complexity. no substance, no layers, just barebones cliche here folks... You've got the hot-headed jock, apathetic student, the overly friendly chick, the perfect girl, the mysterious loli, the uninterested main character. They all fit into little frameworks to a T. As I was watching I couldn't help but think, "Are these guys serious?" I'm failing to think of a show as egregious in its display of its cast (if you could call it that), showing us, in earnest, how completely void of personality each and every one of them are. I was frankly embarrassed.


And let's talk about this terrible main character for a second. If one ever needed to know what not to do when creating a main character for a story, they'd need look no further than this. You may be inclined to believe he is a breathe of fresh air from the "whiny, spineless" main characters that we so often get from these adaptations. But it's just another variation of the same garbage, really. First off, to pull off the "uninterested main character" archetype to any degree of success, you have to be at least a competent writer (see oregairu). It's extremely difficult. The reason is because when you have a main character who doesn't give a damn about anything and has no goals whatsoever (or at least doesn't present them for the audience to know), you run the risk of the audience saying things like, "Why should I even care?" That's the one thing you don't want. Ever. Because if your audience doesn't care, they will stop watching. 


Ayanokouji is bored in every scenario. Even in high tension situations where the mood of the scene calls for him to actually care about what's going on, he doesn't. And this is detrimental to the experience of the viewer. We're conflicted. What are we supposed to feel in situations where the scene is telling us we should be worried, anxious, mad etc. but our main character is looking into the distance with eyes half open, spacing out thinking about fuck all? This is what bad writing looks like. It's simply unbearable to watch if you've not turned off your brain.


There was one scene in the 4th episode that cemented to me the notion that this show, similar to Ayanokouji, just doesn't care at all. Our main character and a girl we had previously seen him personally interact with *zero* times had asked him to pretend to be her boyfriend so that she could let down her crush without them feeling as bad. The problem of this scene is blatantly apparent to anyone who made it to this episode. These two characters have built no prior relationship that merits her making this request of Ayanokouji. To our knowledge, they barely know each other. It was constructed solely to meet the demands of the plot, with no regard to upholding any standards of storytelling. It was kind of insulting to watch; I could picture the guys making this anime on their lunch break having a laugh going, "How unambiguously dumb can we make this show, and still get people eating out of the palm of our hands?"


It was at that moment that I truly realized this anime has gone nowhere and that it will never go anywhere. There is no passion anywhere to be found here. No feeling. No excitement. A grade schooler could tell just how little original thought and care went into the making of this story, its world, or characters. It's just another poor ripoff of something that is already dreadful. I could make this review much longer, criticizing everything in excruciating detail, but similarly to Ayanokouji, I just can't be bothered.

Some shows are so bad they make me angry enough to rant about them, but so far only this show has reached new levels of irrelevance that I experienced genuine ennui for the first time in my life. It's pretentious, boring drivel that makes a teen girl's SasuNaru songfic look like Gilgamesh in comparison.
I keep seeing people claim that the best part of Classroom of the Elite is it's interesting premise for some reason. But, honestly, what groundbreaking concept are they exploring? High school students have to get good grades in school and not blow all their money on video games and dresses? Shocking. Classroomof the Elite presents this scenario like it's The Hunger Games for rich teens except that they still have rich families as a safety net to fall back on even if they are expelled. Nothing is at stake for them, not starvation or basic hygiene because the school offers free necessities and meals. Apparently not even expulsion, because test points can be bought and sold. The buying and selling of test points could've also been an idea for an interesting concept, students being forced to choose between buying food and clothing or spending a hefty amount of money in order to stay in school, if it weren't for the fact that Light Novel Guy and Main Girl have to be the Best At Everything and be the only ones with points to spend. So there goes that interesting idea too. 


But let's talk about the characters for a second. I swore that if the protagonist made one single facial expression in three entire episodes I'd give the entire series a chance. Spoiler alert: he didn't. Light Novel Guy here is just 2kool4skool to actually react or even emote to situations around him. Adding a nihilistic viewpoint to an otherwise-generic Light Novel Guy is an interesting concept, if not for the fact that he's supposed to be seen as a nice guy and not a complete jerk. The first scene immediately laid out the problem with the way the writers treat his character; he wouldn't volunteer to give an old lady his seat, not for any moral reason, but just because he "couldn't be bothered (tm)". I've seen a few critics compare him to a robot, and it's not far off. To give you an example of the stellar dialogue, this is an actual line the main character says from episode three: "I have no objection to this party, and I am taking part." We're supposed to believe human beings talk like this.


Speaking of human beings with dialogue so two dimensional it makes spam bots look like Shakespeare, here comes Light Novel Guy's gaggle of girls. We have not-Yukino Yukinoshita, our main girl, and not-Yui Yuigahama, our bubbly side chick. Comparing the characters to SNAFU is too easy, but low hanging fruit is the sweetest of fruit. The writers seem to agree with me, as both the characters can be boiled down to the tsundere and (spoiler alert) yandere archetypes. Since this is a light novel adaptation with a pseudo-intellectual main guy, I'm assuming at least two more girls on the promo poster fall into his harem as well. Boring is a pheromone in this anime, and no girl is immune. 


But it's okay! Not-Yukino Yukinoshita isn't just here for a forced romantic subplot, she's also really deep! She wants to be the best because she has a brother complex and the only cure is for our Light Novel Guy to save her from being slapped around by her onii-sama because not only is he super smart, he used to play piano so he's super good at dodging kicks! 


Not-Yui Yuigahama is the straw that broke the camel's back and the reason why my score for this show went from a 4/10 and swan-dived into a 1/10. In the final minutes, she pulls back the curtain and reveals the writers for incompetent idiots who not only have no idea how women think, what emotions are, what rape culture is, or how fingerprinting works. It feels like they weren't confident the audience wouldn't like their milk toast main couple and tried to make the secondary love interest completely horrendous instead of giving personality to the characters who needed it most. It feels like the writing of a twelve-year-old stretching their edgy wings. And I feel so god damned bored.


There's one good scene in this series. It's the debate between the two girls and their conflicting moral philosophies. One believes the weak should be culled in order to advance, the other believes the weak should be helped in order to strengthen the group. Both yield the same result. This debate is still boring, but at least the show stretched it's Psych 101 muscles for twenty seconds. Of course, it's irrelevant because Main Girl only changes her mind once Light Novel Guy mansplains the other girl's philosophy to her again just a scene later because watching women change their entire worldviews after a man condescendingly rants at them is the only way Jason, the 17 year old otaku from Milwaukee, can finish. 


It should be noted that the only decently animated shot in the entire series is a close up of a boob being squeezed. In fact, the entire series is void of basic animation when breasts aren't the main focus. In one instance they literally took a still image of a character and wiggled it around in photoshop to give it the appearance of animation instead of actually animating it! Not only is this show uninspired, boring, and borderline-misogynistic, it's straight up lazy. The character designs are hideous at worst and mediocre at best. The sound is for all intents and purposes non-existent, with a few acoustic background songs that sound like studio Lerche let the asshole in the park who's always with his guitar plunk out a melody in a recording booth. It's just bad.


It's fun to hate bad anime. Heck, if all the SAO videos are any indication is downright profitable. But there's nothing enjoyably bad about this show. It's about as fun as late-night paperwork. It's as fun as a root canal without the drugs to alleviate the consistent drilling pain. Anime as a whole may not be a mistake, but this show sure as hell is. 1/10.

After being put off by many reviewers, it's clear that this anime is a hit or miss depending on how you view it. I've never written a review before, however, I'm attempting to in order to justify one of the most intriguing series I've watched to date.
The series' story revolves around Ayanokoji, who is placed in the worst class in the school due to his poor entrance exam grades. While many people trash the story for being too "slow" or "mundane", I feel like the story itself shouldn't be the main focus of the anime but it instead should be seen as something that supportswhat I will be discussing next.


If the story of the school isn't the main focus of this anime, what is? The answer to this is the characters. While many early reviewers see the characters as boring and unattractive, they are only considering what the anime has directly given to them in a blunt way. Nothing about the characters' personality and/or motives are shown directly at first. This should have been obvious by how at the end of the first episode, the viewer realizes they know absolutely nothing about any of the characters' pasts or motives, including the MC.


Youkoso is interesting because the viewer is led to wonder what each character's reasons for doing things are. Of course everyone is boring in this high school, you know why? It's because over half the characters wear masks to hide their true personalities. Actions and clues lead the viewer on a fascinating journey as pieces are put together in a way so that learning more and more about the main character and his classmates has a ton of impact. As more and more is revealed to the story letting the viewer understand the characters, the series becomes more fascinating and understandable, which creates the point that this series cannot be judged prematurely.


Although I won't go too much into the art and music, I can say that I really like both and think they pair well with the anime, being fitted in at right times. Youkoso's construction is slow, but boy is it one hell of a ride once you get into it.


To summarize this review, if you are able to think for yourself and lead yourself to wonder what each characters' true personality, then you will most likely enjoy this anime.

The best way to describe this show to someone who watches a decent amount of anime is "baka and test that takes itself seriously".  
As it turns out, baka and test does not work when it takes itself seriously.
For starters, the basic setting, while it seems interesting at first, makes no sense on anything but a surface level.  For some shows, (slice of life and comedy) this is okay, as deep reflection on the setting is not an essential part of the experience.  However, in a show that prides itself on its deep philosophical aspects, the fundamental flaws in the setting makeengagement impossible.\n
The core plot of the first episode is simply that the students go to a prestigious school, where everything is provided for them, to be bought with points allotted at the beginning of each month.  The loser class that the story follows spends their points frivolously, and is shocked when they discover that the amount of points they have is lowered by their bad behavior.  Their teacher mocks them for not figuring this out, mentioning that she had said that their point allotments were based on merit in the beginning.  The show brings to attention how obvious this was, to the point where I did not even realize that it wasn't supposed to be while watching.  Yet, for some reason, nobody even considered it.\n
This starts the show's trend of lazy writing with selective idiocy on the parts of the characters, where despite being students at the nation's premier prep school, regularly fail to understand basic concepts, rather than coming up with a reasonable reason for the characters to fail and create conflict. \n
Furthermore, along with the forced conflict, the stakes riding on this conflict are equally nonsensical, with the big reveal that any character who fails a test will be permanently expelled.  This is treated like the end of the world, and due to the structure of the series, from the viewer's perspective expulsion of a character would be equivalent to death, being their complete removal from the story.  However, to the characters, if they were already failing with no hope of recovery, expulsion would be an actively good thing, so the only shocking part about this consequence is that anyone in danger of being expelled wouldn't have dropped out or transferred already.  \n
The story then proceeds to use this faulty setting as a premise to try and explore deep and philosophical questions such as "does equality truly exist".  However, this question's meaning is almost completely lost, because when the premise is this divorced from realism, we know that the plot will magically contort itself to drive home whatever moral the author feels like forcing on us.  Characters will act absurdly, impossibly unlikely coincidences will occur, and certain key aspects of society and human behavior will be overlooked, just so that the main character, and by extension the author, can be proven right in his morals.\n
Fiction is an incredibly powerful tool for investigating philosophy, and a well crafted story can do very well as an example of a particular branch of philosophy.  However, rather than doing this, classroom of the elite simply makes bold statements like "equality does not truly exist" and proceeds to simply showcase supposed examples of "inequality" while ignoring all factors that would contest its viewpoints.

I'll get this right out there, this is without a doubt my most disliked show of the season and I believe it to be an objectively bad show. Here's why.
Before I start ragging on it, I'll say I don't mind either of the main characters too much (that said, I'll still tear them apart). Main characters referring to Ayanokouji, and Horikita. My problem lies with the pretentious attitude of the show, the frankly laughable story, and the down right cringy characters and character interactions. Due to the main characters being a carbon copy of the more famous Hachiman / Yukinoshita  (which certainly were notthe first couple of characters like themselves) and the awkward introductions with famous quotes, I get the feeling the show is trying do a few things. Be relatable to students, to be profound enough to spark critical thinking, and then the actual story itself is trying to be grandiose and dramatic to force a sense of excitement.


School settings are popular because everyone has been, or is a student. Everyone can relate to being in school. This anime has done nothing wrong with trying to use a school setting to be relatable. The problem is the pathetic drama, and the narcissistic attempt at philosophy. This show is far too melodramatic. It's trying to cram too many settings into one anime. I can't take anything the characters do or say seriously. The school setting itself isn't an issue. Nor are the unoriginal, less interesting (than others of their kind) main characters. The issue is the drama. It's trying to hard to force drama and some great big power struggle, which would never, ever happen in any kind of high school. It's that kid in the 8th grade trying to act like an adult. It's pretending to be serious, mature and edgy. The only settings you MIGHT seeing something even remotely close to this is in some American Ivy League college. Not in some Japanese private school. Sure you might get some pretty hard core bullying or rich kids throwing money around, but you'll never see some billion dollar completely self sustainable campus. That is because there is no return. If you're going to try and force this kinda conflict down our throats, at least have it be a college / university. This kinda thing doesn't fly in a modern day setting. No way in hell is any country, or business entity going to blow literal billions of american dollars on HIGH SCHOOL. Not to mention a high school with a bunch of luxuries for pretentious teenagers. Things like malls, pools, luxury cruise ships, fucking islands. If you're going to try and be relatable through something like a school, keep the setting realistic. Otherwise you get that contrast of putting a Picasso next to fucking Jimmy who's failed to get a engineering degree and is now trying for an Art degree in modern painting. It's laughable,  and completely incompatible //Excuse the rhyme.


The next problem is the point system. There is literally zero risk involved in having zero points. The school gives out everything you need to survive for free at a no cost. Obviously it's not as nice as the higher priced things, but it's by no means inhumane or even of "bad" quality. The threats and repercussions of having zero points, and going against school rules seem to be non-existant. Everything that is a hard no in the school's rulebook get's brushed off by some bullshit teen logic or some all power Student Council. The only incentive to have higher points is for vanity and to ascend to 'A' class, which itself seems to have little incentive other than bragging rights and the aforementioned vanity.


As I said, the philosophy is down right pathetic and narcissistic. The first episodes opens up with the everlasting "Are humans truly equal" and then breaks into a poorly thought out monologue that the 14 year old high school kid posted on r/im14andthisisdeep. Each episode opens with some profound quote and then proceeds to have an episode completely unrelated to that quote. Every attempt this show makes at being profound, philosophical and mature breaks down to some poorly though out drama between 'D' class and their oppressors which has practically no relation to the quote at the beginning of the episode.


The characters are a travesty. And while I don't dislike them, this complaint encompasses each and every character in the show, including the main characters. All these characters, from class 'A' to class 'D' all fit some boring archetype or stereotypical image. They are completely flat in both dimension and character. They're boring to say the least. From having 6'10 pure muscle bald monks who act like Yakuza, to 5'3 big boobed redheaded airheads that are secretly evil back to 6'10 black men who only speak broken english. The characters are laughable. Everyone praising Ayanokouji as the second coming of Hachiman is wrong. The only relation they have is their intelligence. Ayanokouji is nothing more than your average self insert protagonist. Sure he's more enjoyable than your average lucky pervert harem protag, but he isn't any more complex or better written. Horikita on the otherhand is just a poor attempt at Yukinoshita. Her 'cold attitude' is actually a facade to cover up her incompetence regarding human relations, and her own emotions. Comparing Yukinoshita and 8man is like comparing a Porsche to a beetle. Yea they're both cars, but the difference is jaw dropping.


This story's pathetic attempt at stimulating intellect, refined philosophy, and exciting drama is down right insulting. This show started bad, got worse and ended horribly. It's a failure through and through.

Ok now to sum up all the things that I said up and give a last insight. First this show is NOT like Oregairu, yet it TRIES to be like it. However in doing that it completly misunderstands the core elements of it. You can see this the most in the main character of Ayanokoji. On the other hand Hikkigaya stood out through his alternitive view points, which made him different from the rest of the cast.

Also through the entire show all the characaters felt more like they would come from a show like Asterisk War rather than Oregairu.

In terms of storytelling I like the way the setting is meant to be a "survival of the fittest" type. Yet the comedy and the huge amount of fanservice ruin the serious nature of it. In the end I think Classroom of the Elite is a pseudo-intellectual bait show for people that do not understand the basics of storytelling or characterization. It can be a good time if you can identify yourself with the power fantasy which is the shows MC. If you don't you will have a hard time liking the show and I would not recommend it. that, after a solid start, got worse with each passing weak.

What if the most elite students in society were placed in one incredible intense school, pitted against each other to become the most elite student of them all? If this question even moderately intrigues you, then turn around because the Classroom of the Elite does not have any meaningful answer to it, in fact, it has nothing worthwhile to say at all.
This show is a head-shaking enigma, it proposes intriguing questions but never answers them, it feigns depth, and it pretends like the twists can't be predicted from miles away! At best you'll get some fleeting fun by watching "elite" high schoolers running around andsolving trivial issues, at worst your time will be wasted and your intelligence will be insulted. It excels at nothing and falls flat in more than a couple areas.


Episode 1 was a moderately interesting opener. Students who were considered the best of the best collected into one school, they were given full responsibility for a great deal of money awarded to them once a month. At the end of the first month, to the surprise of no one but the idiotic cast, the money was not replenished. Perhaps the show was trying to establish a theme of materialism, but if this was the truth then they failed to follow through with it. I wasn't sure if it was good when I first watched it, but I had hope that with more development it could become something special. The episodes flew by and my hopes were left unanswered. I suppose I’ll have to delve into it eventually so I’ll do it now, the story is simple and I didn’t like any of the characters.


The school is separated into 4 classes, A, B, C, and D; the best students being in class A, then the worst in D. The underdog class D was the one the story followed, and in the class was the narrator/protagonist Ayanokouji; a mild-mannered guy (with a mysterious past!!) who served as a relatable joke dispenser in the early episodes, then he was shuffled into the corner so the real focus could take center stage, the ladies. Whenever the other members of D class were developed it felt like the story's original conceit was growing less and less plausible; for a school that is meant to be strictly for the most elite students, it's full of a lot of idiots. Most of the issues Class D had were caused by the stupid mistakes of its students. Whenever a conflict was contrived to add tension it would simultaneously showcase the idiocy of the class and increase plot holes. Plot holes are really the least of this show's problems, it's sad I feel this way but my standards have been lowered due to the shitshow that was Summer 2017. Beyond the plot holes, most of the "twists" that occur in this show seemed unearned and the rest of them were unbelievably predictable. 


You can make the argument that the characters were given traits; beyond that was nothing, all of them were one-dimensional. There are no characters in Classroom of the Elite I will ever think about after I finish the review. None of them resonated with me in the slightest, but that isn't enough to insult a person. Most of them are a single trait, stupid, shy, wise, bubbly, bland, but there were some who got characterized as sicko-perverts that were reminiscent of the appalling supporting cast of Hajimete no Gal (you really shouldn't want to be compared to a show like that but if that comparison excites you then, by all means, enjoy both shows). Anyways, there are some villains, they are your typical stoic and condescending types and they're in the classes above D. They're rarely on screen and only exist to add someone to root against and occasionally contrive tension from.


It was almost as if the writer intended to cross through every trope they possibly could on their way to the finale, and oh what a finale it was. 

It wasn't until episode 7 that I really understood the magnitude of this show's flaws; it was the obligatory fanservice episode. I don't have a problem with fanservice, this show is loaded with it and it was rarely intrusive until this one moment. The infamous episode starred some of the male supporting characters in the titular class D. They try to plant cameras in the girl's bathroom to spy on them and it is played off in a disconcerting and perverted way, but I can only assume they thought it would be funny and relatable high school humor? Who actually thought this would be a good idea for a tv show? (Based on the MAL score a frightening amount of people.)

The supporting characters that led the infamous episode 7 were never funny and only succeeded in creeping me out, it was only made worse by the fact that they were followed throughout the episode and their gross conversations were being overlaid with fanservice shots at the pool. After those infamous 20 minutes, I could not watch the show without feeling cynical towards this disaster. Maybe I'm biased because I hated that episode so much, but I think my arguments still have value. 


I feel like I've said enough about the plot and characters so I'll briefly mention the sound and visuals.


The opening is great! The song is awesome, character portraits fly in and out, quotes in random languages zip past the screen, it really was a joy to watch in the early episodes. However, as the episodes counted past I began to realize that the depth that the visuals alluded to would never be explored in the show. It's just another one of the show's gimmicks meant to draw in an audience and fool them into thinking the events transpiring onscreen are more interesting than they actually are.

Music is also used throughout the show to make scenes feel weightier than they really are. For example; organs and a volley of stringed instruments can be heard over entirely random scenes that follow villains. The music sounds great, but it really loses power as it's used over and over to very weak effect. 


The art is totally passable, nothing unique but not bad either. Characters look fairly simple, no outstanding designs, nothing to set them apart from one another, I struggled to remember their names. The student uniforms are generic and express nothing. Nothing about the school stands out visually beyond having a shopping mall within it. 

Lastly, a message to you, Classroom of the Elite, showing a random and loosely related quote every now and then does not make you profound, it just makes you pretentious.


Score Breakdown:

Final Score 2.8/10

(Story 1/10) (Art 5/10) (Sound 6/10) (Character 0/10) (Enjoyment 2/10)

People tend to think that because an idea seems uncommon on paper, it is already good.
No, it is not. A plot may seem to be as attractive as possible, a character may appear to be interesting for not following a common stereotype, but if they are not developed correctly, or at least, they are not well used in the universe that the same serie propose, then can’t be said that they are good. This is the case.
Two things to keep in mind before continue reading:
1. Minor spoilers ahead.
2. This is an ANIME ONLY review.
Youkoso Jitsuryoku Shijou Shugi no Kyoushitsu e, also known as "Classroom ofthe Elite", this name already summarizes us what the series is about: a prestigious school where only attends "the best of the best", students are separated by categories and where a point system is managed according to the test results, which are necessary to literally survive on this island/school. Of course the best class usually has most of the points, while the worst, that is, the D class (where the series focuses) have few or none, so the aim of these students is to improve on their exams for get more points and survive, even think ambitiously and try to get down to the other classes. If we ignore the fact that no one in the D class except the protagonist group was so smart to not see the obvious working of this system that promotes competitiveness and instead they all believed that they would receive 10.000 points at the end of the month just for their pretty faces (¿is not it supposed to be a school of elites?), we have a plot that, on paper, sounds very good, and can give rise to a story with an interesting development.


Among other positive aspects, the animation is very good, has enough fluidity and is very colorful, the character design is generic but very well done (especially the design of the girls). The soundtrack is meh, not bad but it is very forgettable and were few times where highlighted, however, the serie has a good handling of audiovisual quality and a decent sound direction most of the time that knows how to make the few scenes where the sound is important (scenes of intrigue or "revelations") are able to impress and trap the viewer.


And it's up to this point where the only thing that I can speak well of the serie ends...



Now ¿what is the problem with this show, having an proposal with so much potential? Just the fact that they don't take advantage of that potential, and instead, the series focuses only on exposure: they show you the MC reflecting and understanding more how the system and the school works and acting when required, but not the reason of his acts, they show you several background characters moving as if they had some evil plan (¡with background funeral music included!), but in the end little or nothing happens, they show you how their protagonists pretend to make their class rise range, but they are so rough that they don't even bother to relate to their classmates to carry out their class, which they show you as mere extras or victims for the protagonists to shine more. This is not a story of "how the D class improves and rises in rank", the protagonists go on their own march and the rest of the class cares little or nothing matters, and when the show tries to give them characterization or at least something of space on screen in the moments where they are important, it doesn't even do it well (Sudo, Ichinose, Sakura, the sensei, etc.).


Another aspect is that many of the arcs feel disconnected, contribute little or nothing, are unnecessary and in some cases is not explained how things were given (eg, the survival test), arcs that were only introduced to force the plot and the drama. With all this the central thread is lost, it's not known to what point the series will arrive or that pretends to show you in reality, everything ends up being boring and disinterested.


The serie pretends to be a serious and dark story, with issues of discrimination and arrogance on the part of high-ranking classes, people moving in the shadows and the D class being victimized by being the lowest link, but again, the series resorts to the exposure of this arrogance and this "dark atmosphere" (the upper classes bullying Sudo, Ryuuen punishments to the members of his "gang", the almost rape scene, the president machining things, the girl with the stick with the bald guy talking incoherently so that they seem to plan something "interesting", etc.), all in an exaggerated way and nothing subtle, to the point where the series ends up being immature, for not knowing how to handle such issues with the seriousness that is meritorious and instead uses them to pretend to be intellectual and interesting, or in the worst case, to "shocking" the viewer and thus disguise the poor writing and development of the serie and its characters, even shows you situations cliches and fanservice that not even the case.


I have always said that it's not bad to have cliches and fanservice as long as you make use of them in a way that are acceptable to see, this is not the case ¡because even the fanservice is explicit! other series show you subtle scenes, fleeting or according to the situation: falls, wind raising skirts, rays of light coming out of nowhere, etc. Here they put the tits in the whole screen without more, without conceal, without having more nothing on the scene, not even people talking, and with no other goal but to do you fap with that. This creates a contrast to what the series shows, and instead of being serious and interesting, ends up being ridiculous. Basically the serie pretends to be something that it is not, it resorts to exposure to hide its failure of plot development and shows you exaggerated and unnecessarily explicit situations in an attempt to prove maturity and ends up being the opposite.


Pretentious, that's the word that describes the show. I know that this term is often used as a "generic argument that people usually use to denigrate a job they do not like" as some say out there, regardless of if it really applies or if those who use it know what really means, but I would not use it if in this particular case it doesn't apply, and does apply. With all that I mentioned before, the series insists that the same must be taken completely seriously, despite the great failures in development, despite their cliche characters and exaggerated situations to the point of ridicule, all this creates a great contrast to the heavy atmosphere. If I try to take it seriously, I can't, because the atmosphere is very forced and doesn't go according to everything that happens on the screen: arcs that contribute little or nothing, cliches in the middle of a plot that tries to be dark, irrelevant characters doing nonsense here and there and "serious" situations so anticlimactic and explicit that end up being simply stupid, so the seriousness that the show intends is not transmitted. And if I don't try to take it seriously, I can't either, because the plot tries to convince you that EVERYTHING that goes on screen including the most insignificant nonsense and the most exaggerated situation possible, is serious and dark, situations that obviously you can not take as such, and even try to put comedy, which is so dry, forced and simple that ends up being shameful and cringy. On more than one occasion I ended up banging myself on the keyboard of the embarrassment for such pathetic attempts to "be comic."



Another negative aspect is that the series does not know the term "subtlety": every time a situation occurs, they show it in the most crude, explicit and anticlimatic possible way:


—Starting with the same plot. Being an elite school that seeks to form highly skilled people, a fairly realistic goal ¿is the competitive environment so exaggerated so necessary that even people are talking about "destroying the other classes"? ¿is necessary the discrimination? ¿are necessary the "evil plans" only to expel a single student? ¿is necessary a Btooom! style Survival Test in a high school with relatively normal students? Situations that have little or no place in the genres that the series handles are literally forcing the plot to generate dramatic situations that ultimately are nothing, because the development of the arcs is so random that they do not transmit what they want to show.


—Horikita's traumatic past and the fact that she feels such inferiority to her brother that she literally changes character to script conveniences. Just as they show the brother as an almighty whose only presence is terrifying, and a sort of evil final boss who went so far as to almost hurt his sister to "show her that she can never reach him." It is not necessary to exaggerate the situation to the extent that it is so unbelievable.


—The Kushida's revelation, who at one point changes from a loving and friendly girl to a soulless bitch, and the way she showed it was so cringy: screaming, flailing and threatening the MC with saying that he raped her if he reveal it, ¿are you serious? If you are going to show a dark side, at least do it maturely, otherwise, it's like something edgy and stupid.


—The constant fights with the other classes, which they show as a kind of mafia that punishes its members when they don't fulfill their duties and always go for the most violent and problematic option possible, as if they were real criminals ¿Would not it be enough to show the friction between classes without wanting to make the whole situation happen as a kind of war between yakuzas?


—The Sakura's trauma with the potential stalkers, exaggerated to the point that they show a man like a sick and obsessive who almost raped her, which was not necessary to show his problem (just make it clear that she was being harassed and make the pertinent complaint was enough) and shows how the serie handles a serious subject in a very immature way, because of course, all men are disgusting that the first thing we do when we see the sexy photos of a girl is harass her to try to rape her... Also the fact that she is an excessively shy girl who shows her provocative photos both on the internet and in the middle of a serious trial to increase her confidence with herself, but then she implies that she "doesn't like to show a lot of skin" and it bothers her that they look at it in a "lustful way" ¿is not this a bit contradictory?



Now, let's talk about the other aspect that ends up completely burying this series: the characters. I would like to remind you of what I said at the beginning: that something looks good on paper or looks different at first glance doesn't imply that it will be good. That the characters, mainly the protagonist, do not seem to be the common ones in this type of stories doesn't make them automatically good, in fact in this case, they are all lousy (some more than others). All are flat characters and completely inhuman but with a kind of "plot twist" to make them look more interesting and complex, complexity that doesn't really exist:


—Ayanokouji, our protagonist, at first he looks like someone bored, but in reality he is someone analytical, who only observes what happens around him and he draws conclusions about it, plus he does not want to highlight. In this sense it is very similar to Hachiman, which is why many consider him a good character, and in fact sounds like a good approach ¡SURPRISE! it turns out that the guy is super smart but he gets mediocre ratings apparently on purpose, is an expert in hand-to-hand combat and just for being him, he is surrounded by how many girls who "notice how special he is" ¿why? The most silly excuse: he was a laboratory rat created to be perfect, and not people, show a flashback of his past is NOT characterization or character development if they do not show how he develops his way of being and think from this fact , which they never did, they simply said "MC is perfect because like that he was created", that's all. Based on the above the main problem arises with this character: he doesn't really have a background to make his actions coherent, and then you realize that it is not that he is boring, he simply has no personality, but even so the series doesn't waste opportunity to make him shine, since everything to him goes well, everyone talks about him, everything important involves him and seems to be the only character who thinks and acts rationally, basically a perfect example of a self insert character and a Gary Stu. He is with the same face always, immutable to everything that happens even his own actions ¿How can I believe that the protagonist is living a tense situation (when the president confronts him, for example) if he doesn't express it? Besides, because he doesn't have personality or characterization, you don't know what really drives him to act, you can not take his actions seriously because what motivates him to act is basically non-existent. He only acts because the plot says so. He doesn't move the plot: the plot moves him. Even though he is not a bad character at all, his inexpressiveness makes it somewhat unpredictable (even though you know that Almighty MC-kun will always be there to save the day), which plays to his advantage, however that is not enough for make up for all the bad. And understand this for a good time: That a protagonist doesn't be your typical dense and rough MC does NOT automatically make him a good character, much less "the best MC of the season".


—Horikita is the typical elitist bitch who believes herself superior to the rest, despises the whole world because "making friends is unnecessary" and is all the time with her arms crossed to show superiority over "scum". Currently she is the one that really wants to raise the class despite treating their classmates as trash. ¿Why? again, ¡SURPRISE! she also possesses a typical traumatic past (which is never explained), an apparent inferiority complex toward her brother, the student council president, and a lamentable desire to show him that she may be at his level, all in a pathetic attempt to make her see her not so rude and that you feel empathy for her. Then, the rude and super serious elitist who tries to do everything for herself (although she knows she should collaborate with others, which she never does) becomes a submissive to which the MC has to rescue, and a kind of tsundere badly made to justify his mood changes at the convenience of the script. She is the inconsistency made character... and speaking of conveniences of the script: it is funny how she does not trust anyone to believe that they all have a double face, but she fully trusts Ayanokouji who obviously hides many things (and even threatened her by gossip) just because "he saved her" when all he did was to be in the place indicated "by casuality" (that is, when the plot ordered him). Curiously she was the only one to have something vaguely close to a development (yes, THE ONLY ONE) as we saw how little by little she began to trust and appreciate her classmates more (although she is still rough). Apparently several of these scenes must have been from another character, and I saw a lot of people whining about that, but in fact this change was partly a success, mainly because the other character in question (Karuizawa) was never introduced correctly ¿would not be something strange give too much space suddenly to a character we do not even know? Instead they gave more space to a previously established character, so it was not a bad decision at all. As a side note: that Senjougahara-style compass scene was very pathetic, and we don't talk about the tickle scene, a bad attempt to make it look more moe. I don't' mention the bathroom scene in Chapter 11 because it clearly was important to the plot ¿right?... ¿¡right!?


—Kushida is the typical cheerful girl, with more breasts than brains who wants to be friends with everyone, but in such a sickly way that a lot of people, including me, find her annoying to see, but ¡SURPRISE! it turns out that the girl actually hid a kind of second, darker and manipulative personality, all in a very pathetic attempt to give complexity to the character and to "shock" the audience that perhaps did not expect that. ¿But do you know what's the worst? That second personality was never explained, never showed the background and also had absolutely no impact on everything that happened in the rest of the show, so ¿what was it all for? A cheap way to make a character look interesting and keep people to the expectation. They literally sold smoke.


¿Now you see why I said that such complexity does not exist? All characters are just cliches already seen with a plot twist that tries to fill the void of a real characterization.


The rest of the characters are not worth talking about. Sudo is the typical rude and troublesome boy, Ichinose is another less annoying Kushida, Sakura the typical excessively shy girl and complexed by his past and/or actions, Hirata the popular, kind and attentive guy (SURPRISE! He also seems to have a "dark" personality), the president the typical evil boss "because yes" who is even more elitist than his sister, Ryuuen the gang member, Ibuki the Rem— I mean, the submissive dependent without personality, Arisu the mysterious loli THAT DID NOTHING, etc. ¿Do you see how all can be described in a single sentence? The worst thing is that no one was given some space even to know them and that they come to import, in fact, in their respective arcs they were treated more as victims or plot devices than as characters ¿and do you pretend I take all your plot seriously with that cast of characters?



The dialogues and the interaction between the characters are almost as bad as themselves. To name one of many examples: Chapter 4 was particularly stupid, another "friendly girl" of another class receives a love letter, but since she doesn't know what love is, she makes the only "logical" choice she has: Asks MC, with which she hasn't crossed more than 10 words before, that he pretends to be his boyfriend to reject the girl who sent her the letter... ¿do you realize how contradictory and senseless it all sounds? How many cliches in such a forced situation, literally a beautiful girl with big tits fell from the sky to the MC without personality of turn and asked him to be her boyfriend "because yes" so that in the end he gave a sermon to her and he remains as a mature guy... a complete situation of self-insertion that also adds little or nothing to the development of the series (like almost everything else up to that point). Then in chapter 5 we have the almighty MC advising a "shy girl" to be honest with herself and only with these simple words that anyone could say is enough to make her fall in love, from this point this character (whose excessive shyness is FREAKING ANNOYING, "Best Girl" my balls) only dedicated to fanservice by trying romantic approaches with the MC... Ah, and let's not forget in Chapter 11 when the MC tells Ibuki that he trusts her and immediately she falls in love with these "Pretty words" like a whole Rem— submissive dependent ¡Of course he is not a self-insert! Similar situations happened throughout the series, which are summarized in boring dialogues and sometimes so edgys and out of place that give pity, and relationships so forced that feel false, the characters are not related naturally, but because the plot says.



Seriously ¿Why do you praise series like this and score them so high? At this point more than one will think that I am a bitter, but if you look at my list you may notice that I am someone of simple and irreverent tastes, and doesn't prevent me to enjoy series like this or any other series that even I may consider bad, but in this particular case, when the flaws are so conspicuous, the plot pretends to be taken so seriously by putting such ridiculous and stupid situations that it is impossible to do so, development is disastrous and the characters are so horrible and poorly characterized, even with low demands (because it would be idiotic to expect a "Mushishi" or a "Rakugo" from series like these, right? The correct thing for these genres is to lower the requirement to have something at least enjoyable) the same mediocrity of the series prevents you from enjoying it.



This BY FAR IS NOT AOTY. And no, it's not that "the show started good and became bad in its second part", the series already started bad and became worse with the passing of the chapters.



I will end with a phrase that summarizes this anime: that something looks good on paper or looks different at first glance, doesn't imply that it will be good.

Basically, if anyone has seen Oregairu then you will probably see the parallels. in fact, as someone who has seen Oregairu, and liked it, I see more than parallels - I see a ripoff. Except it isn't a good ripoff - by making the protagonist hyper-competent he can't Hachiman (pretend not to care and play scapegoat at the same time) his way through the story, and that takes a lot away from the narrative. In fact, the protagonist Ayanokouji reminds me most of Kirito - a soul-less, personality-deprived screen for an anxious otaku to project themselves onto. the two main girls - Horikita and Kushida,play the roles of Yukino and Yui from Oregairu, respectively, and fail to varying degrees, but I cannot elaborate on why because that would be a spoiler (who cares though?). 


Another show this reminds me of is Hyouka, where they also have detective work in school. except that there, it is done in a very classically Sherlockian fashion (with references to the works of Conan Doyle and other great detective authors) and it looks insane. here, it's just plain bullshit because they gloss over all the details that actually make a detective subplot fun and go straight to the artificial drama that this show is awfully fond of. 


Another similar show to this one is this season's Kakegurui - both are set in an elite school, both have a cast of obnoxious and unnecessarily-dicky characters, both have red uniforms and both have fan service. except Kakegurui is a cock-tease with a gambling twist and it flaunts this shamelessly at every chance it gets, while this show aspires to being intelligent in the same way that the BBC version of Sherlock does. and it doesn't work. because telling the audience that the story is smart doesn't make it so - as an author, you have to show it. 


this show's usage of pretentious quotes reminds of Call of Duty 4, except that they're a little less out-of-place here, but, of course, the series fails to make full use of the opinions of great historical thinkers.


As someone who has been to a boarding school I find the premise of this show just plain retarded. shutting people off from the outside world for THREE YEARS is a terrible idea - they will begin to view their artificial world as the real world, and you don't want that. what you would get in that case would be "elite" assholes who would know nothing about how the world really works, and hence be completely inept once they graduate. no meritorious university would want to touch these people with a 3 metre pole. and not giving them the rulebook? why? to create some contrived hoops for characters to jump through to increase the runtime? I must say I'm not hopeful.


I've seen 4 episodes so far and I don't like how bored I am of it, but I have recently found that I am more entertained by bad anime than I am by good anime, so I fully intend to finish this one. who knows, maybe this "elite" classroom can surprise me.

STORY: 7/10
CHARACTER: 10/10
ART: 8/10
SOUND: 7/10
ENJOYMENT: 9/10
OVERALL: 8/10
I knew this anime would be different just based on the quotes at the start of each episode and I wasn’t wrong. This show takes pleasure in cheerfully stunning its audience by strongly commencing with an interesting setup that only gets diluted as the show proceeds yet still manages to land strong with its ending! The story is nothing unique since it revolves around students trying to top their class by making more points. What works in this standard setting is the play along of strong, interesting characters which help elevate the plot to an enjoyable watch. The pointsystem introduced into the story felt oddly fresh, working in the show’s favour since it brought about essential character development. This leads me to the last arc, which was both a blessing and a curse! The pacing issues became more evident here which hurt the show’s momentum. (Personally, I felt like the story started losing steam once they got out of school). And now this anime has some backlash due to that 1 fanservice episode, I don’t mind it much since I understand it’s importance. But I would have rather opted for this episode to be allotted on story instead because it could have helped wash away the few plot holes that exists! However, the way how this arc wrapped up was more than satisfactory, making it my fav arc of the season!\n\n
What truly sets this anime apart is its characters and the point system really helped establish their different personalities. Furthermore, we get mini arcs for various people that help shed light on them without taking away the spotlight from our main characters. (Solid Writing!) I liked how each class was represented with respect to individuality, from the bullish domain of class C leader to the dual leader contest among class A, etc. This really helped establish the students of other classes as real people rather than some background characters, which also meant they presented a real threat to our MC as well. If I were Ayanokouji, I would seriously watch out for Sakayanagi because she played her cards very well this season! (I feel like she will be a hard roadblock to climb for Ayano since she might be on to him) And some character arcs do not conclude, most probably left for another season. Horikita is the main girl of the show who’s an interesting person, coming across as a mere tsundere at 1st glance but turns out to be just more than that. Her surprise relationship with the student council and interesting setup of falling from grace (metaphorically) to class D has her uptight and fixated on a single goal. Yet it’s this ironclad sight of hers that alienates her from the rest, making her unpopular and unapproachable in class. But enters a boy and her life changes! Slowly, but surely, Ayanokouji breaks down her defences and his efforts aren’t wasted because his constant efforts makes Horikita more likable, eventually ending up on good terms with her classmates. \n\n
And now to Ayano who’s easily the most unique MC of 2017 and by far the best aspect of this show, I mean the air is filled with intrigue as you slowly peel off the layers from this guy! It was a pleasure to take this journey with him despite the show trying to present him as an uninteresting character. Behind his deadpan look and those cold, lifeless eyes reclines a manipulative and calculative mind which misses nothing! His attention to details will catch you by surprise and his attitude to problem-solving makes us spellbind to him since it provides a stimulating mechanic to the already evoking plot. I mean look at how well he was able to tame the once smart and proud Horikita towards the end! Ayano is viewed and presented in the anime as a troubled individual with a shady past. His early life is just as mysterious as his present (Only shown a few short scenes of where he grew up) but once you understand how he was raised, you get to know Ayanokouji better. (And the teacher knowing all this was astounding) You recognize with his way of thinking, his view of all other people beside himself, his obsession with winning by trumping over everyone, his choice of avoiding all spotlights in order to pull every string by controlling everyone, all of this starts to make sense once you glimpse at his past. Yet you don’t fully realize this until the very end when the curtain is lifted to reveal the final act! This is because the story itself presented him in a manner of making me think the best for him despite the anime dropping hints of otherwise! We were being misled into thinking he wants to connect with his new classmates and cares about what they think of him. But that was all an act! Which is why the twist at the end really hammers you with reality by opening your eyes to the truth. The truth being, he prefers to remain in shadows, he prefers the role of a puppeteer, they all are playing his game! After all he did build a strong class by uniting everyone behind a capable leader which gives him the safety of time and space to micromanage everyone! He is devoid of any other emotion aside from winning, whatever else we felt never really existed or at least they never came from his side. Top marks to the writer for perfectly giving us viewers a full realized character!  \n\n
The art style for characters were good and distinguishable. (For me Ayano’s look reminded me of Karma from “Assassination Classroom”) I liked how you could tell at 1st glance which characters would be popular and which a troublemaker. The animation was nicely portrayed delivering on the Action and Drama well. The best thing were the eyes of the characters, they had a certain incandescent glow to them which always managed to get my attention. The OP is deceptively cheerful while ED is more on the calm side. The soundtrack is particularly good during the upbeat moments of the story. Voice Acting was good on both grounds, though the Subs were a tad bit better than the Dubs.\n\n
In conclusion, I had a blast with this anime! It’s nowhere Perfect but it far exceeded my expectations and that counts as a win! While pacing was a little off and some parts of the story were predictable but the sheer writing brilliance in the character arc of Ayano brings a whole new level of uncertainty to the plot which only increases the audience excitement. The show leaves on a high note, doesn’t give everything away but grand enough to make us desire for more so let’s hope for S2. Because I am very thrilled to see how Ayano is going to reply to the following, “Icarus did no heed Daedalus’ Warning”

Is it dread; is it disappointment? No, it's even worse. It’s welcome to the classroom of the elite’s opening line: “If I may, I’d like to pose this question: Are human beings truly equal?” In a single moment, the writer has already shown that he is a talentless hack and has exemplified in a neat sentence why this show is awful. He began with this line thinking that it would make him look intelligent, but all it did was make him look edgy and stupid. Starting a story out with an obvious, rhetorical question shows that youwant to show off how cool and smart you are touching on “deeper” theme like you ever even knew what that meant. And the way the show precedes every episode with a title card displaying a quote of a famous philosopher makes me want to take the author with me to the grave from how disappointing it is to see the names of people whose intelligence not just dwarfs, but annihilates the “intelligence” of this clueless writer of this light novel on his piece of shit that he cobbled together. Another thing this awful opening line tells me is that the author is not discrete at all - not one bit -, and he has to constantly shove everything down the audiences’ throats because not only is he not good enough to show instead of telling, he has to make sure that they don’t miss of spoonful of shit going down their throat.  The final thing this line tells me is that this show will take itself to seriously and be even worse for it because the writer probably can’t write well enough to make serious scenes that are both well crafted, smart, and engaging.


	Let’s talk about how this man knows nothing about writing characters.

It’s obvious that if you took a picture of the cast of My youth romantic comedy SNAFU and pit it against this shlock, you’d see the blatant “influences” (borderline theft) that come from that other, better show. Little did he know that not knowing what makes a story work when trying to incorporate elements of it (or the whole thing) into your own show, doesn’t turn out very well. How many times do you find someone that when you get to know them really, that all they have for personality is one trait and one trait only. None. When every character only has one-character trait, they become boring and predictable because they only react one way to everything, they resemble a computer more than a human, and they’re not layered enough to be relatable and engaging to watch. They act so serious and so gangster to the point where it’s not only fake but childishly fake. They might as well all be playing pretend. Actually. If they were all playing pretend, I’d be more engaged. At least then I’d know the characters weren’t taking this seriously which would lift off some of the disappointment. 


	The characters may act like rocks, but the crap that leaves their mouths… It’s all a big mesh of boring blah. I don’t know how else to describe it. HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA HAHAHA. Yeah right, try again next time when you can actually write worth a damn.


	A little interjection here. I want to say how most to none of the logic adds up in the show when you think about it for more than a second. He doesn’t know how to write and he also has no grasp on the concept of logic.


	I think it would only be fitting to close with the structure. The one that this show lacks. Scenes in this show just don’t mesh together. Not once scene. Now, its no secret that the Japanese people love their high school anime. This can be easily seen in the fact that every season, more than 40% of the shows are related to high schools. This is also a fact that school has been one of the most cliched genres. However its also true that every once in a while, we do receive shows that have something out of the ordinary and can be described as interesting and fortunately enough for us, this show too falls in the later category. 
The Classroom of Elites is an anime produced by studio Lerche and is based offthe light novel of the same name. At first this show had the vibe of orgairu , with a loner  protagonist and an antisocial female lead , However  ,as the story progresses ,one will realize that the show is skillfully hiding its true colors and is  rather  dark and has many hidden  themes and unique characters which makes it different that most other shows. Also the show skillfully completely shatters the idea of the normal education system seen in many other high school shows, and shows a completely new system where rather than grades, you need other skills to survive and also how you need to play dirty with others to reach to the top. It is actually a  representation of the true face of today's society .


As I already said, The characters here are actually the key element of the show and most of them have more than one dimension . Many characters seem to have a different personality than what they show to everyone. The protagonist on the surface might seem like a average guy with average grades and he doesn't stand out much. But watching the show will make you realize that there is a lot more to him than meets the eyes. He is extremely strong, both academically and physically and has an unexplained dark past but he tries to hide all of his skills in order to not stand out and lead a peaceful life. Horikita, The female lead has a more linear personality, She doesn't have friends and nor is interested in having one .She is also determined to get promote to class A , tho she has realized that it would be impossible without aynokoji's help .The side characters also have very diverse personalities and no two people have same personality. Like kushida ,who tho seems to be friendly and kind ,actually has a very dark and sadistic personality which not many are aware of. The characters here represent the dual faced nature of the society and how people misguide other for their benifits. For example ayanokyoji's character clearly represents the type of people who use others as tools and manipulate them. 


The show is also more of a unique take on the genre and the system of schools and it also covers many dark themes , like discrimination and inequality in the society and also things like social hierarchy which is not many anime, especially ones like this cover . The different characters also represent different types of people and personalities in the society .The pace of progression of the story is somewhat irregular as the things were going very smoothly during the first half, tho during the second half , the show seemed to have slowed down a bit with little interesting or major events . The order of the events and pace of character development and also character relationships had been altered and were really different from the source material. The Music of the show is great. The op is really well done and it creates a hype for the episode and the ed is nice and slow paced which smoothly ends the entire episode. The animation is also pretty fine and the art style is great (especially those eyes).


The D class is full of characters with great potential but were still thrown in garbage due to their defectiveness. Almost everyone has a certain element of defect which holds them from getting a better class. They are shown to have a normal face on the cover, but deep inside many of them have a twisted personality which they don't want anyone to find out, Ayanokyoji for instance, perhaps has the most twisted personality as he views people as tools and is ready to sacrifice anything for his gain, and is good at manipulating others. People like Hirata and Kushida also have a dark personality which is rarely seen and is not known by anyone.


One of the major plus points is the treatment of the characters. The show actually treats the characters well and they also have certain level of sensibility in them, which is sadly not seen in most other shows. On many occasions we can see people actually putting their brains to analyse the situations and not just go with the flow ,And this actually stops various moments from becoming cliches . best example is when ayanokoji was asked to pretend to be ichinose's boyfriend. Tho one major problem is that there are there are too many characters and most focus is given to only a few ones and others are not given enough time, so all this prevents many of them to get the screen time they deserve. But there are various ones who easily caught my eye , without even having been shown more than once or twice. Also the show still has various plot holes and mysteries  and there is a lot of potential for a season 2, however we can't really be sure about such things. 


Overall, This show is not for everyone. There are many like me who would enjoy it but also this new concept is not suited for everyone. To me this show feels fresh and is seems different from most of the other high school anime. The characters are truly remarkable and the story is good enough to keep the viewers interested. All characters are memorable and interesting, especially the protagonist. The show also covers various themes about the society and shows the dual faced nature of the people. And for everyone who are not bothered by the feel of this anime, All of these things combined together makes for a great 12 episode watch, and makes you crave for even more.

Overall it should be a good anime but they rushed it and just destroyed potentially a very good anime. If you're haven't watch it, I recommended to hold it and wait the 2nd season.

Ah, another LN adaptation with a name so long it's practically a story in and of itself? What could possibly go wrong?! 
Now, YJSSK isn't exactly... bad? (I suppose). It's definitely not the worst basic LN adaptation I've seen, but that's not exactly a merit considering the standards. It suffers from pretty much the same issues any of these LNs suffer: it's set in high school. Now, I know that the target demographic are the teenagers, and this cheesy stuff is written for young boys & girls, but it always feels just... wrong, especially in terms of dialogue. How old is our MC? 14-15? Andthe very first time he speaks, he says "Is this world equal?". I mean... 


Furthermore, another issue that shows of the similar nature share is that there is no story. There is no 'ultimate goal'. Now, that would be fine if it was SoL (that way I would have just skipped it), but it's not. It wants to have a narrative. It wants to have a narrative so bad it can't help but keep beating viewers over the head with pointless exposition, 'mysteries', and attempts at some profound, epic storytelling that just goes nowhere.


Besides the basic set-up, it doesn't have anything unique to offer (well, to be fair, even the set-up has been done before). It just feels like you're watching a bunch of pretentious kids live their daily lives in uninspiring fashion. 


The drags of the story just keep on coming, as it tries to branch itself out far too much to the point that it all just loses meaning. What's MC's goal? Help MG get to class A? Look, if you're going to make it that bare bone, just don't have the ultimate goal in the first place. What's the MG's goal? To get into Class A. Why? 'Cause she's insecure, I suppose. There's no coherent narrative to glue all the things that are happening together, so it just feels like a bunch of events strung together in a somewhat chronological order. 


While pace isn't absolutely atrocious, it is far too slow for the type of a show it wants to be. It wants to be a flimsy comedy. It wants to be a mystery. It wants to be a romance. Thing is, ALL of those genres thrive on thrills. Comedy requires constant movement. Mystery demands constant thrill of discovery that leads to more questions. Romance needs constant banter. Yet, this show has none of that. Comedy is rare, and it relies on your basic anime formula. Mysteries are thin and are left hanging for no reason (ex. 1 'mystery' is introduced in the 3rd episode, and it is referenced maybe 3-4 times until ep. 8. By that I mean that MC just reminds us it's there, but it moves nowhere; that's absolute garbage way to do it). 


Suspense is lost, light mood is as rare as days when I don't hate people, romance is absolutely nowhere to be found (well, if we exclude like 2-3 cheap moments that ONLY viewers can witness and understand), absolutely nothing of importance happens. And then we get to ep. 7 and 8. Pointless fanservice episode followed by half an episode of fanservice and half an episode of something random that has NO tie in to whatever narrative they were going for. Going to the island to survive? Wtf? Where did this come from?! 


In terms of characters... eh, I suppose it's not as bad as the story. Although no character has an actual, normal motive for doing anything (well, aside from 1 guy who wants to play basketball but can't 'cuz he's dumb; and the general motive of 'we gotta study cuz points). In the end, we're left with a bunch of holier-than-thou teens that keep shoving ideologies onto one another, and we're just asked to side with whatever character we see as 'right'. 


MC is your basic edgy-teen that's as big of a hypocrite as you can find. He keeps saying "I just want to remain passive and pass these years", yet he keeps meddling into everyone's business like there's no tomorrow. Yeah, sure, he has that 'cool' factor about him (again, mysteries that go nowhere and are barely mentioned), but cool isn't = good character. 


MG is just a girl with bro-complex. There you go; that's her 'thing'. Every character in this anime just has a 'thing'. MC is 'cool'. MG is 'insecure'. 2nd MG is... eh, that's kind of a spoiler. That basketball guy is loud. These aren't characters, just basic templates. At least, save for MC, most other characters stick to their template. Until... 'plot'... demands otherwise. 


In terms of enjoyment, I guess the anime is passable. It's average, at best. I felt bored during some episodes, but for the most part it managed to keep me interested somewhat, which is why I managed to finish 8 episodes, and will most-likely finish the entire show. Can the last 4 episodes change my view of the show? Probably not. Without even seeing them, I can already imagine it'll play out similarly to the show's previous... arcs? Some classmate gets in trouble, MC swooshes in to save the day, everyone's like 'whoa, pay attention to MC, he's really, REALLY mysterious'. 


It doesn't help that episodes 6-7-8 all feel like completely different shows. Absolutely NOTHING connects ep. 6 to 7 or 8. It's as if they just skipped an entire volume of LN and left the viewers to connect the dots themselves. Sure, whatever. 


Thanks for reading.

Classroom of the Elite follows in the footsteps of anime like My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU and Assassination Classroom that offer a more jaded perspective on high school life. For this anime, school life for the students runs on a merit-based system where students earn points to cover everyday living expenses based on their grades and behavior on the campus. The main character of focus in this series is Kiyotaka Ayanokouji, a seemingly ordinary student who is part of the first year D class where the school's inferior students are placed.
Classroom of the Elite's jaded approach on high school life is that equality's a shamand it's showing the students that life is completely unfair. The school system within the series is deliberately set up to weed out students oblivious to the manipulative and deceitful nature of many of the staff and students, valuing only those with the intelligence and abilities to see through them. Much of the anime's focus is on Class D overcoming the school's adversity to improve their academic performance and behavior, as the points they earn for their livelihood is dependent on everyone working together cohesively as a class. An interesting element to relevant characters introduced within Class D is that each student has some sort of personal flaw that led to them being entered within said class, such as Horikita's inability to trust others and Kushida's genki gal personality being a facade. There is gradual growth from some of these characters to overcome their personal flaws, though not to a sufficient degree due to the anime having an inconclusive ending.


Another entertaining element to the series are the games of strategy that the classes have against one another. Classroom of the Elite runs on a few episodes arcs where the members of Class D often have to plan and sort out how to overcome a specific crisis facing their class. Each arc devotes enough time to explore how the characters are thinking through developments and the plans they have in mind to either avert the situation, swing events in their favor, or allow more to be revealed about the circumstances of the current situation. For the most part, the series did a great job dropping hints, and offering concise logic and motive with the actions performed by the characters within each arc.


These solid story elements aside, Classroom of the Elite does have its fair share of hiccups. The series does usually get derailed by some fan pandering that detracts from its more cerebral focus, in particular an episode ran in the middle of its run that is mostly an excuse to feature fan service from showing the characters in bathing suits for a pool episode. Kiyotaka's very character is also a bit of a double-edged sword. While shown to have hidden intellectual talents that he's obviously hiding from the class and hints dropped of having an ulterior motive for being at the school, the series doesn't dabble too much into his character's backstory and never really has a chance to develop due to the anime's inconclusive ending, an obvious dilemma due to its light novel source material still being ongoing as of this review. The very premise of the series could also prove to be a barrier for some viewers, as many characters in the series can be quite unlikeable at many points to go along with the anime's more cynical perspective of high school life.


Overall in spite of its mixed reception, I actually found Classroom of the Elite to be rather solid in the execution of its premise exploring the struggles of Class D and showing some solid psychological focus on some of the characters thoughts and machinations. While having its flaws, its premise is still unique enough where I'd at least recommend checking it out at least once.
